Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. Comment: Definitely time to change OCA to UCA.  Also time to consider making some adjustments that would help (but not eliminate) the high cost of medical care.  For example, consider giving patients the legal right (which they do not currently have) to enter a binding agreement not to file a lawsuit against their medical provider except in cases of gross negligence.  In return, the provider agrees to charge less for visits and procedures (the amount to somehow be determined by actuarial tables....I'm a doctor, not accountant).  The bigger "fix" to this problem is to set a national goal of doubling the number of positions in medical schools in the next decade or two. Every year there are thousands of qualified applicants who cannot gain access to a limited and overly competitive number of slots.  Having been in the medical education field, I know this as fact.  We need to increase the supply of providers (greater access and hopefully lower or slower rising costs).  There are steps to be taken.

Comment: There is confusion about veils. A veil is defined in the dictionary as a piece of fabric worn over the head OR face. Most people probably associate it with the see-through face coverings worn by brides, but "taking the veil" (becoming a nun) refers to the head coverings that used to be traditional in religious orders. The faces were usually exposed.

Muslims use two separate words. A hijab covers the head and hair. A niqab covers the face except the eyes. (A burqa is a full-body covering with only the eyes exposed.)

Comment: A few more tidbits of info for you that probably did not know.

In Canada, the very first organised education took place in Catholic schools. Other denominations followed suit. Eventually, Protestant denominations nominally abandoned their involvement in education. That this was done only nominally is well expressed, for example, by Egerton Ryerson's words (he spearheaded the 1846 School Act), who believed that it was part of the Government's mandate to be a social agency forming children in a 'uniform, common, Protestant culture,' regardless of their individual family backgrounds. He, and like minded people pushed for funding for Protestant schools from publicly collected taxes as opposed to charitable donations. Thus, they became 'public schools'. Catholics kept their schools. Eventually the 1867 British North America Act, primarily because of Quebec, guaranteed 'public funding' also for Catholic schools.

Since then many things have changed, but anti-Catholic sentiments persist.

Comment: My sincere sympathy to Ms. McBain and her family. 

"The dots are clear now," she writes.  And the first "dot" she lists, I believe, is the crucial one: "the untreated anxiety as a child that led him to self-medicate ..."  I may be naive, but "self medication" doesn't start until the person's able to do so--as, perhaps, a young teenager.  It's that untreated "anxiety"--a vague term--that appears to be the (childhood) problem here.  Yet, the focus is on what came next: drug abuse.  By then, I suggest, it was too late.  

About half-way through the piece I started looking for a mention of the root cause...and finally found it near the end.  "...in treating substance-use disorder and concurrent mental-health disorders..."  Concurrent?  Probably. However, Jordan appeared to have manifested symptoms years before "substance-use disorder."

Comment: I bought Flake's book, which was published during the summer. As I mentioned elsewhere, his criticism of Trump was unceasing during the primaries - and after. He never jumped on the Trump bandwagon even though he had to know it would probably finish his Senate career.  His hero when young was Barry Goldwater. He was Executive Director of the Goldwater Institute. His choice of title (and cover design) were quite deliberate.  He is very conservative on economic issues, but he is pro-immigration - sees immigrants as one of our nation's strengths (I agree), and supports a path to legal residency/citizenship.  He has been slammed by the extreme right for using the Goldwater legacy - he is just a "slimey liberal" in their minds, not worthy to call himself a follower of Goldwater. Comment: "It would result in more choices better quality and prices."

Not necessarily.
What it will necessarily bring is an inability to control production, as is presently the case with grain, beef, pork, fruits & vegetables, etc. When prices are good, producers understandably want to increase production. When others (understandably) do the same, we have overproduction, price collapse, farmers who can't pay bills and bankruptcies for farmers and sometimes even creditors like local feed stores.

That could lead to a supply shortage (fewer choices), increased imports (often lower quality) and higher prices. 

Food security is something we take for granted. Some day something will cross our path to remind us that a nation's food supply is really a matter of national security..

Comment: It's kinda like three different doctors examine the same guy.  The first one says, "Dude's coronaries are 95% occluded.  He's way overdue for a heart attack."  Second one says "Did you see his MRI?  He's got an aneurysm big as an egg in his brain.  Could cook off at any moment."  Third goes, "WBC are 85,000 and platelets are 20k.  This man's in end-stage leukemia."

I make the following points:

1)  All three doctors could very well have made correct diagnoses.  All three lethal conditions could coexist.

2)  Because any one of the three is lethal in itself, the question of which one "prevails" is mainly of academic interest.

3)  Nevertheless, this fellow's goin' down and the best thing to do is simply start measurin' for a pine box.

Comment: I am glad you got to the arguments instead of going after the actions of the gun control folks.
My thoughts are that we need to make it harder for the "nuts" to get guns, but there was no indication this guy would have been seen as "nuts". 
We agree on he alerts for such large purchases. That is a starting point. 
We disagree that there are legitimate reasons for such purchases (except for a gun collector). Gun collectors could pay a large fee (since they can afford many guns) and that money used to pay for regular checks of their activities. 
You justify a "security force" because some people feel a need to protect their wealth. I disagree. How many people feel that need? I am for something that is a pervasive need, but not if there are just a few. Is that need rational when there are banks to keep stuff, alarms and safes? 
Your defense of keeping an arsenal is that it is justified if people feel a need. But who makes that call? Anyone who feels a need for an arsenal?

Comment: If the NHL, as it should, went with a different scoring system, so that wins in reg were worth 3 pts, it would go a long way to eliminating the possibility of a team making/missing the playoffs because of its record in extra time.

Beating another team in reg should be worth more than beating that team in 3-on-3 OT, or worse, the SO.

Fla is presently 2 pts behind Bos for the 8th playoff spot, with a game in hand.  TB sits 1 pt behind Bos, also with a game in hand.  Bos has 13 wins in reg, TB 14--Fla has all of 7.  Not even close.  However, if the NHL awarded 3 pt for a win in reg and kept 2 pts for a win in extras, then Bos 50 pts, TB 49, Fla 42.

It matters.  

Soccer does not use SO to decide games in reg, that's only for playoffs and tournaments where a winner has to be decided for the series to continue.

Comment: I am in a similar position to the original letter writer to Mr. Pape, a 30+ year CDN employee who slowly acquired shares thru DRIP.  

A couple other  considerations-
1.  the complex calculation of adjusted cost base over time (stock price, stock splits and especially the US/Cda exchange rate fluctuations over 30 years)
2. the safety of the dividend - IBM cut it's dividend in tough times in the past, it may do so again.
3. the company's future is complicated - it has seen decreasing revenue for 4 straight years under CEO Ginni Rommety (i.e. from 100B to about 80B in 2016) - 5 year return is down over 21%. Rometty's departure would be positive (financially and for employee morale), but there would be uncertainty as well with the new guard
4. in my opinion, most employees are extremely pessimistic about the future growth of revenue - the I/T competitors are very nimble and lean now and it's difficult to imagine a future where IBM can significantly ever grow revenue again.

Comment: Re: Charleston shooter's "criminal record"

No, the 72-hour limit had nothing to do with his getting a gun.

Federal law (18 USC 922(g) and (d)) applies to those convicted of, or under indictment for, a crime punishable by more than one year in prison. The Charleston shooter was charged with (not yet convicted of) the crime of possession of a controlled substance. Under South Carolina law, that's a misdemeanor. The case documents refer to "charge code 0179" - maximum of 6 months in jail.

The only question is whether a single charge (without conviction) means he's an "unlawful user of, or addicted to, a controlled substance". The federal definition of that term (27 CFR 478.11) says an inference may be drawn from multiple arrests, a conviction, or a drug test - it doesn't say anything about a single charge without a conviction. Perhaps an admission of possession would be enough? (Arrest report alleges he admitted possession of suboxone without a prescription.)

Comment: Many mushers put females in heat in front to keep the male dogs racing. Here's just some of the documentation:

“I had heard of using a dog in heat to your advantage, the philosophy being that hormones can give a weary dog team something else to think about. I decided to try it and unhooked Nickel from her tug line.”

– Frederic, Lisa. Running with Champions, Anchorage: Alaska Northwest Books, 2006

“She [Dolphin] came in heat about half way through the race.”

“I simply put her in front instead of the back. It worked. We went like a pack of mad rats for 500 miles with those boys chasing Dolphin and her trying her best to run away.”

– Seavey, Mitch. Lead, Follow or Get Out of The Way!, Sterling: Ididaride Publishing Company, 2008

“Revelation, the female in heat tied to the stanchion in Ruby was Canon, a main leader. Jeff [King] says the dog is really keeping his male team dogs moving.”

– Runyan, Joe. Winning Strategies for Distance Mushers, Sacramento: Griffin Printing Co., 1997

Comment: Good opening sentence, and a good description of the process. Kudos to the reporter. To be sure, this is a top down process, starting with legislators funding planners via an abstract request for proposal to plan something, such as the transition out of OCCC or the upgrade of the canal. Indeed, those selected then look at what can be, draw up the possibilities accordingly, and then parachute into the neighborhood with their ideas or 'plans' and see if the 'hood' buys into them. Clearly, this reporter had fun watching them while they looked for people from the hood to engage and get 'feedback' - so it doesn't help that this wasn't well attended. This 'hood' is a working hood, so the planners didn't meet and greet those with discretionary time on their hands, as in Waikiki or Waialae Kahala, only a few who didn't have to rush to a second job on this particular night. What's the answer? Talk to old-timers, to Romy who has been there for decades, or those with that stature. Then go plan.

Comment: Thank you for the problem, professor KS. I finally got to it tonight.

Based on a website calculator, the length of the arc from Tijuana to Brownsville is 1,263 miles. I added an extra 12 miles to reach to both coasts for a total of 1,275 miles. After little geometry and trig, and assuming that one can actually resolve land features at/near their horizon, I calculate that that height above the Earth is around 25 miles, give or take.

Of course, that's not outer space, but at that height one would need to turn their head through about 170 degrees to see the darn thing, and near the horizon it would be difficult or impossible to perceive. So, I'm guesstimating that to take in the entire thing with reasonable resolution it would be near or above the boundary of the atmosphere and where space is accepted to start.

I enjoyed this. Do I get an A?

Comment: Separatism in Quebec is the result of conflict between two 18th century colonial powers, with one swapping New France for what it considered more valuable colonies. Territories then belonged to rulers, not the populations who lived there, that concept would come later with democracy. The populations came with the territory, nobody asked them for their opinion.

Then the new rulers had to decide what to do with the populations. Some assimilated easily, others did not. The Acadians were deported, the rest of the French colonists could not be so easily disposed of, so some accommodations were made, and more negotiated over time, which allowed enough political and cultural autonomy for that parallel culture to survive and even thrive in Quebec. 

Separatism today comes from those descendants of the original colonists who refuse to accept  the present political structures and want their own country, and those are a  minority.

Comment: I've done both, and disagree.  The stress of waiting tables is far worse than the stress of the kitchen, and income is completely dependent on both restaurant popularity and the whims of management in scheduling.  Some shifts are astoundingly lucrative while others see only 3 hours at less than minimum wage.  Wait staff are dependent on the cooks, busboys, bartenders, and customers and have to suck up to all of them in order to do a good job.

Cooking, on the other hand, is hot and dirty.....but you can blow off steam any time you like, the hours are steady, and, if you work in the right place, can be highly creative.

Comment: "I am the bread of life" said Jesus. John 6:35.

"Now as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed, and broke it, and gave it to his disciples..." Matthew 26:26.

If "bread" is good enough for Jesus it's good enough for the rest of us.

Your reference to king also gives me the chance to show a piece of Roman cultural imperialism. You would be aware of "INRI" on crucifixes. Well, that was originally in three languages: Hebrew, Greek, and Latin, when put on the Cross to mock Jesus ("Here is Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews").
In the intervening centuries the Hebrew and Greek have quietly disappeared, leaving just Latin. That of course was part of the process of making Latin the "official" language of the Church, when in fact the Mass was said in Greek in the first few centuries of the Church.

Comment: She is clearly not asking for "more money".  Those are your words.  She is saying that cutting an already thin education budget will harm students and thus, the quality of citizen we have in Alaska.  When our students are not educated to an acceptable standard, then they as a whole will not be as successful in this competitive world. When Alaska has a bunch of poorly educated people in the state, our standard of living will decline, others will come in and take the better jobs, and Alaska will suffer with more social and welfare issues. Yes, a quality education costs a lot, but it is an investment in an asset for a community, not a liability. It pays back in capable people who can work, innovate, and contribute to a stronger economy for all. So even those without children in the home but still paying taxes, you are still benefitting. Long term investments are often difficult to see, but the rewards will be worth it for Anchorage and all of Alaska. Remember: a school is not your enemy.

Comment: Alaska's OCS management is stagnant and has been for years.  OCS tends to have a high turnover in middle management.  OCS needs to recruit upper management team members that have expertise on how to provide family reunification programs that work.  Back in 2008, Congress passed the Fostering Connection to Adoptions Act.  States, including Alaska receive a minimum of $1.3 million annual for every 300 adoptions that they arrange.  Informed people know that Alaska Native children make up 62% of Alaska's foster care system.  It's likely higher now.  The vast majority of children adopted between new born and 4-years-old are adopted within or less than a year after they're removed from their home.  Parents with addiction problems are at the highest risk of losing their children because FCAA allows states to put children up for adoption after they've been in the system for 2 years.  Tribal members adopt less than 1% of their own children.  It's staggering.

Comment: A clarification of this good article is necessary. The Daughters of Charity were not founded by St. Vincent and St. Louise until 1633. What was founded in 1617 and was Vincent's first group to found was the "Ladies of Charity", a group of lay women who first responded to the needs of the poor. Perhaps this is a typical mistake, of thinking Vincent started first with "religious" orders. In fact he did not and even the Daughters and Congregation of the Mission, founded in 1625 were not founded as religious orders but as active groups, not bound by cloister or other religious order rules. This year we are celebrating the 400th anniversary of that original foundation of the Vincentian charism. Over 9000 Vincentians of all kinds(including lay St. Vincent de Paul  founded by Blessed Frederic Ozanam) will gather in Rome October 14 -16 for a symposium and Pope Francis will address us. I am delighted to be a Vincentain priest of 51+ years. Peace!

Comment: I represented the State in dealing with its unions from '88 to '06, most of the time with the DOC as a part of my assignment. The only thing difficult about dismissing a CO who has used excessive force, was negligent, or "unduly familiar" with inmates is that labor arbitrators tend to be sheltered lawyers and intellectuals who get freaked out by the jail environment and decide that the CO couldn't be expected to behave well in that environment, so they'll give you some discipline but they'll put the CO back to work, but you still have discipline on the book and you can get the CO to act right or you can get him/her again.   It all depends on the State administration; if they're interested in keeping things straight, they can be kept straight.   Some are more interested than others.

Comment: This article has some important points, but I think overlooks two key ones.

First, some of the issues faced by "remote and isolated Indigenous reserves" are issues faced by small and isolated communities anywhere in the country, whether they are indigenous reserves or not. 

But more important is overlooking "the obvious"; none of the problems unique to isolated indigenous reserves ("no malls where they can go to the movie"; no sidewalks on which to ride their bikes; "lack of clean water, housing, adequate heating, even in the school"; students ... “don’t have positive role models and environments.” ... “and the cycle is just going to go on and on and on.”) are solved by educating the children and are fundamental flaws of the reserve system. Without viable industry in and around the isolated communities nothing will change. At some point we need to recognize those reserves are the problem and not part of the solution.

Comment: The more Cook shrinks his sub-groups the larger percentages of consensus he fabricates. He had to create 7 sub-groups. These are the three sub-groups he used. Group 1, (64 papers) explicitly endorsed AGW. Group 2, (922 papers) explicitly endorsed AGW but did not quantify human effects. Group 3, (2,910 papers) implicitly endorsed AGW but was ambiguous of exactly how. 

Only Group 1 (64 papers) explicitly endorsed AGW out of 11,944 papers. The largest sub-groups disagrees with or has no position about AGW. He left out four other groups that did not fit his pre-determined outcome. This paper hardly constitutes a sampling of 100% of climate related scientists globally to arrive at 97% and their consensus.

So, the 97% consensus of scientists globally, explicitly, supporting AGW is a lie, by Cooks own words and "data" and his paper would not pass for a masters thesis in college.

Comment: I don't dispute that Lt Col Raymond Wilfrid Boyden was awarded the DSO while tending to men under fire. I do object to a fanciful, self-serving story with an unnamed Canadian general, a supposedly awarded Victoria Cross, an unnamed villainous British general, a cartoon fight in the streets of bombed out Rome, and the suggestion that the DSO was a consolation prize. Yes, "estaminet" is a French word more appropriate to a story about the Battle of the Somme. And "brig" is a naval term. And Joseph Boyden inflates the number of recommendations for a VC to 7 from the 2 in his father's obit. Joseph is showing disrespect for his father's genuine service to Canada by making the bogus claim that his father was "the most highly decorated medical officer in the British Empire." Although not an officer, Cpl Frederick Topham actually was awarded the Victoria Cross. Joseph can't just make stuff up without citing sources. Not when it's supposed to be factual.

Comment: You are probably right. When I was a middle distance runner several decades ago,  I had a few runs  at night where I felt I could fly forever. Then my knees went kaput. However, if you have been sedentary all your life, running can seem so intimidating that it is tempting not to do anything at all. If you do get out walking, it's amazing what you can encounter, even in the most mundane neighbourhoods. Bird life, gardens, wildflower s, happy goofy dogs, happy, goofy middle aged ladies (that would be me, hello), little libraries, free stuff left outside houses, funny little houses with eccentric lawn ornaments. And the poles aren't for the halt and lame, they give you upper body strength. That way you can avoid gyms. Now Those are boring, and smelly.

Comment: Oocytes for Toxidia Plasmosis are found in 20-30% of soil samples taken from around the world. It can survive in soil for well over a decade. It is found in approximately 30% of produce grown in the United States. Basically, it is pervasive in the environment, and it can be spread through contact with infected soil, meat, etc. if it was a primary threat to monk seals, nene geese, and other wildlife​, they would all be long-extinct by now. Comment: If we're really focused on opening the presidential election...and all other elections...to wider participation and a more inclusive electoral process, we would be working toward "preferential balloting", also called "rank order" balloting.  Such a system allows third-party and independent candidates to participate on a far more "level playing field."  Currently, voters must worry that their support for such a candidate might actually and inadvertently help elect the candidate they least favor.  

The suggestion to adopt a porportional distribution of electoral votes instead of "winner take all" is interesting and would significantly change the strategies of presidential elections...The importance of 'battleground states" would likely diminish and we'd see a system which would, I think, more mirror the popular vote.  

Interesting stuff...................Gary Crum

Comment: Not everything you hear on talk radio is true.   I won't say that unions didn't have influence over the management of PERS/TRS, but the State has never bargained retirement benefits with unions beyond whether or not the union was in PERS or its own plan.   In the early days the State's objective was to get unions into PERS/TRS rather than their own plans because they had more control.   State employee wages and benefits, something I actually know something about, unlike you, are not based on the price of oil.   Oil revenue may dictate how many employees the State has, but its effect on what they are paid is indirect.   Tier I PERS dates back to 1961, when the only State employees who were unionized were the Marine Hwy. employees, who had their own union-run pensions.   I paid what the State asked for my PERS benefit; you can cut it when you can pry it from my cold dead fingers.

Comment: Quoting directly from the constitution:
Establishment

223. The South African Reserve Bank is the central bank of the Republic and is regulated in terms of an Act of Parliament.

Primary object
224.
(1) The primary object of the South African Reserve Bank is to protect the value of the currency in the interest of balanced and sustainable economic growth in the Republic.

(2) The South African Reserve Bank, in pursuit of its primary object, must perform its functions independently and without fear, favour or prejudice, but there must be regular consultation between the Bank and the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters.

Powers and functions

225. The powers and functions of the South African Reserve Bank are those customarily exercised and performed by central banks, which powers and functions must be determined by an Act of Parliament and must be exercised or performed subject to the conditions prescribed in terms of that Act.

Comment: Supply management, the Canadian Wheat Board, post-WW II veterans' benefits and the CHHC mortgage program together and in concert with fairly consistent growth in the Canadian economy and progressive policies to ensure some fairness in opportunity and income distribution made Canada the relatively prosperous, stable and inclusive country we enjoy today.

Without these, urbanization and the growth and growing diversity of Canada's population and economy would have been much starker and dysfunctional.

This is not to suggest that redesign and scaling back or ending such programs (including supply management) are not now warranted given changing circumstances,

What isn't useful, is overreaction against programs on an ideological purist basis that doesn't give thoughtful consideration of what should take their place.

Comment: Nathan Bedford Forrest is still all over the place in Tennessee. A state park is named for him, a bronze bust of his image watches over the state Capitol, and a grandiose monument of him resides at his grave in Memphis. But his most gripping presence may be along Interstate 65, running through Nashville, where there’s a can’t-miss-it statue of Forrest—he’s atop a horse, with a sword in his right hand, a pistol in his left, surrounded by Confederate flags. Forrest was a Tennessee-born lieutenant general in the Confederate Army; after the Civil War ended, he focused his energy on the Ku Klux Klan, which anointed him its first grand wizard. The 25-foot fiberglass statue was created by lawyer and sculptor Jack Kershaw, who is best known for being among the string of lawyers hired to defend James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of Martin Luther King Jr.

Racism is found in the eyes of the Confederate HOLDERs.

Comment: Nice article overall, though I think Brooks fails to emphasize the importance of raising children in a marriage as part of the moral aspect he mentions. While children are not a focus of some marriages, they are a focus of most marriages, especially during the 20 years or so it requires to raise a child. When a marriage fails or never even occurs and children are involved, it is a great moral failing of their parents with lifelong and even inter-generational consequences to them and their own offspring. More than any other factor it effects their income prospects and their likelyhood of having their own successful marriage. So while all the aspects Brooks mentions are crucial in choosing a good and lasting spouse, if children are expected to ever be a part of a family, that marital commitment must also be built around the children's needs and can be a great source of strength in maintaining marital commitment through difficult times.

Google "importance of marriage to children."

Comment: I've been prescribing Suboxone to patients in Florida for some time, like many Canadian provinces Florida requires special training and I could not agree more,  making this drug more readily available to prescribers as an option to treat opoid addiction would be tremendously helpful, but I would like to throw in a word of caution, in the end, there is no magic bullet or easy solution to this problem, without a significant support system, these patients will almost always relapse, in short, support, continuing encouragement, education and prevention is needed and in the end is more important than any medication... Opoid addiction (like that of alcohol) (likely permanently) alters brain chemistry and once an addict (unfortunately) always an addict...

Comment: It seems the authors (or ADN editor) left out some important context in this article.  China (yet not America, sigh) is a signatory of the UN Law of the Sea Convention.  As the article states, the treaty sets territorial waters at 12 nautical miles from shore.  However, the law also sets that "shores" do not include artificial islands made from uninhabited corral structures or lifeless "rocks."  It also extends that possession 200nm for exclusive economic usage.  China violates this part of international law as well by claiming the entire South China Sea including parts well beyond China's 212nm claim and well into various other nations like Vietnam and the Philippines.  IIRC China lost a case a few years back in regards to its claims.
Regardless of how legally empty its claims are it still calls on other nations to respect their claims with threats of "You are causing an international incident."  The US rightly enjoys free navigation through most of the South China Sea.

Comment: 2007
A buyer with 10% Down and a $100,000 annual gross income.
At the time rates were ~4.99% and amortizations were capped at 40 years
Maximum mortgage amount?
~$630,000
Moving along…
2016
A buyer with 10% Down and a $100,000 annual gross income.
At the time rates were ~2.49% and amortizations were capped at 25 years
Maximum mortgage amount?
~$630,000
But then something happened, in response to rising prices and an apparent lack of understanding as to basic math, our Federal Government changed the rules.
2017
A buyer with 10% Down and a $100,000 annual gross income.
With rates still ~2.49% and amortizations still capped at 25 years.
Maximum mortgage amount?
~$508,500
The exact same household with $100,000 annual income, impeccable credit, a 10% down payment was told, in this very competitive market with a 0.27% arrears rate, a group of households that made it through the 2008/9 meltdown just fine, that now, in 2017, they needed to have their purchasing power cut back by ~$121,500.

Comment: There are a few errors in this article, for example:

1) In the 3rd paragraph, an inconsistency in the target for the detection rate of crimes against women.

2) In the 5th paragraph, "...a strong correlation of race, class and wealth nevertheless emerges in the Statistics SA 2016 Demographic and Health Survey". It isn't clear (at least from the Key Indicator Report) whether intimate partner violence is strongly correlated with any of these, especially because the prevalence statistics are not subdivided by race or class.

3) In paragraph 8, the numbers 17% and 16.7% should be 10.3% and 1.6% respectively. A similar error  occurs in paragraph 11 (mistaking lifetime vs past 12 months exposure).

4) In paragraph 21, “...all eight metros where HIV prevalence levels are 80%” This is probably a mistake, even if it refers to prevalence in a high-risk group.

Comment: The states are allowed to divide their electoral college vote proportional to the popular vote, and a few states do that.  But the Constitution requires the President be elected by the Electoral College, which does give the smaller states more votes relative to their population.  The only way to change that is by the amendment process.  And the smaller states will never ratify it.

Hillary won the popular vote in Colorado, but we have more Republicans in Congress than Democrats, and an equal number of Senators.  If Colorado were to vote its electoral college vote proportional to the popular vote 5 of our 9 votes would have gone to Hillary and 4 to Trump, which would have widened his lead.

Had the election ended in an Electoral College tie and it went to the House, each state only gets one vote, which goes to the party with the most seats.  Trump would have got that vote.

Comment: EMTALA does not allow you to get treatment for anything but an emergency medical condition, and the only obligation is to stabilize, not cure or resolve the underlying causes of the emergency. 

It works like this. You show up at the ER with severe shortness of breath caused by your lung cancer. The  ER staff has to screen you for an emergency medical condition and can't delay the screening while asking how you're going to pay. Severe dyspnea is an emergency, so the ER staff would likely treat you with several medications. They may do imaging and admit you if you're still significantly laboring to breath. You might even get a chemo or radiation treatment or two. But, as soon as you are you are stable, the hospital can and likely will discharge you. 

No one has an obligation to further treat you until you are again in severe distress. 

Plus, you remain liable under normal civil law for the cost of your treatment. The hospital can and likely will bill you and pursue collection.

Comment: The question is not whether to provide universal health care but whether to do it by means of universal health insurance. Most people agree that the present system of providing health care to uninsured people is suboptimal. But many people think that trying to provide it by requiring insurers to cover people who their actuarial analyses indicate are bad risks doesn't work.

Every system of providing care falls short of the goal of providing everybody with all the care they want at no cost to anybody. no system is genuinely "universal."

Comment: Sustainability will be achieved when the City of Eugene and Lane County work together to manage sprawl. Among those who have been cheerleading SW-SAZ are several who own vast tracts of land outside the UGB, but who have no restraint in developing those areas for their own comfort and/or profit. 

Why not control all sprawl -- single-story commercial buildings, large-acre lots with McMansions, gated residences on forest tracts?

To my eye, Capstone is sprawl and blight all at once. Density is not the answer to our problems. Smart planning has to begin with intelligent collaboration that includes a careful study of what makes Eugene "Eugene" and then putting feet-on-the-ground to recognize why theory fails when put into practice.

I am proud of Eugene at this moment and hope that what we have learned from this experience can be shared with other cities worldwide who are going through the same struggle. We can save the planet, but not by destroying neighborhoods for density's sake.

Comment: Nothing more than lazy leadership and lazy citizenship. Generally speaking, the primary role of government is to organize the services it makes no sense for the individual to provide for themselves (roads, schools, law enforcement, emergency services, ect.). These services cost money. Consider Anchorage's roads. They are a wreck -- not to mention the sidewalks (when you can find them). Not repairing the roads costs every driver money in increased auto maintenance & damage to delivery vehicles -- the cost of which is passed on to the consumer. Lack of sidewalks increases pedestrian/auto interactions (EMS & police costs, healthcare, ect). There are no free lunches. As a politician, it is your moral obligation to spend taxpayer money wisely, listen to your constituents, and be a leader working for a better society. As a citizen, it is your obligation to pay taxes, & keep politicians honest through involvement (& quit expecting free stuff in the form of public infrastructure & services).

Comment: The report you refer to in your opinion, was accomplished not by experts, but instead was "prepared by" political antiche' of President Obama, and is hardly what I would consider credible. Comment: Yup, I'm one. An adult, I mean.  And yeah, I had trouble. 
I got 3 correct answers. And one of those was a guess.  
I learned more (useful, practical) math after I was 30 years old than at any time previous.  Because the incentive was there: I now had my own company and had to make a profit or I wouldn't be able to feed, clothe and house myself.  It was that simple. I had a lot of computation practice...learned to crunch numbers really well; every invoice I mailed was full of 'em and sometimes spent hours making them accurate (not just for me but a host of suppliers and contractors I put to work.)  Learned to estimate extremely well, too. Learned where my true financial worth lay, so I didn't waste time/energy. I paid myself my first salary 2 weeks after I began operations, and  operated the company profitably for 20 years.

But I'd probably be in the 50% failure group.  

And so, the moral of the story is...

"Needs must."

Comment: Well, who knew Dead Man Walking was also an opera--I didn't, and am intrigued to learn it is. 

The film did something brilliant. It didn't depict the crime until the end, when the lethal injection was being pumped into DeRocher's arm. The scene in the woods, which unfolds as a flashback, is unbelievably savage--one of the most brutal rape-murders on film, especially given the age of the victims. The woods are murky; the perpetrators are drunken brutes; the victims are lifeless dolls. 

I understand the opera reverses this order and opens with the crime. Interesting how these decisions need to be revisited with different media.

Comment: With the bill in effect
All of the 270+ presidential electors from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes among all 50 states (and DC)—thereby guaranteeing that candidate with an Electoral College majority.

It would NOT be direct elections.

The founders created the Electoral College, but 48 states eventually enacted state winner-take-all laws.

Unable to agree on any particular method for selecting presidential electors, the Founding Fathers left the choice of method exclusively to the states in Article II, Section 1
“Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors….”  
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive."

Comment: Couldn't agree with you more. But the argument used by those who want to protect government budgets is, "Show me where to make the cuts." If the answers were obvious, they already would have been done. The savings aren't obvious--but the potential is still huge and could be identified if we looked at every department of government and asked: 
1) What programs are really necessary and which are not?  
2) Can necessary programs be handled more efficiently by the private sector?

6) Etc..

The reality is that many would oppose such a process, because government inefficiency creates more jobs, union dues, overtime bonuses, and thus bigger pensions after retirement.

Comment: I would not be surprised at all if the Rox do nothing at the deadline. Or, if they do make a move or two they're pretty minimal. 

I say this as I believe this team has the potential to be very good in the next two to five years and has little chance to beat the likes of the Dodgers or the Nats this season. It makes no sense to me to mortgage your young talent just for the sake of making a move or to satisfy some within the fan base. It may not be the sexy thing to do but in the long run I think it's the best thing to do. 

That being said, the only "big" move I could see them making is to give up a young arm or two (Pint, Castellani) in a package deal for a bat and a reliever. I think the bat would need to be a guy with a economical contract through 19 or 20 though, I don't think they're in the market for a rental through the end of this season only. Reason I say this could be the move, if a big one is made, is the amount of young talented arms currently at the big league level.

Comment: There is some basic math missed by Dear Supreme Leader and his cohorts. Yes, there is a sizable trade deficit between the two nations. The inexpensive goods were mostly machinery, production equipment rather than retail goods we the general public see in the stores such as Walmart. The companies import these goods to keep their costs down. If they increase to the level of the proposed tariffs, it will severely impact the liquidity access for these enterprises.

Banks have covenants in place on their debt facilities that they extend to various businesses. If the cost of production and goods zip way up, it impacts the margins on the end product and the sellability of that product. What happens next is a credit review will be called under the debt agreement. If the defaults cannot be cured within the prescribed period a negative event will be called. The bank steps in and places the business in remediation review.

In other words, we will see more business failures. Jobs lost.

Comment: Im not generally afraid of heights.  I am afraid of unsafe situations where I might fall.  I worked on the 33rd floor of an office tower and there was an outside patio on the 32nd floor; I loved that patio.

Being between jobs, I took a job doing siding on a monster house.  12 foot high ceilings, three floors, the house construction alone is costing the owner a million dollars.

Then I got the (*sarcasm*) joy of using a ladder jack scaffold.  10 feet long, only a foot wide, and there are no guardrails and rather than starting the siding from the bottom (like I thought we would), we started a good 15-20 feet in the air.  I have to hold up 16 foot boards, and pull them towards me to get them in their grooves, which, given that there is no handhold on the side of the house means that I'm in effect trying to pull myself off.  They told me scaffolding - I expected normal scaffolding, not a platform held up by two ladders seated in mud with rocks below.  Talk about terrifying.

Comment: The GST replaced the Manufacturers Sales Tax, which was unevenly applied.  On top of that, the GST is a value-added tax.  A company only pays the GST on the value that it adds to a product or service, meaning that it deducts the GST it pays on inputs.  So, in answer to your question, the economy did not tank with the introduction of the GST because it did not introduce an across-the-board 7% tax on everything, as your post implies.

Comment: Kurt, one of the bears you mentioned was a black bear, so you seem to be lumping the two species. Black bears can already be hunted in most of Chugach State Park, including most of the upper Eagle River valley, and most of JBER. Brown bears can already be hunted in most of Chugach State Park, including upper Eagle River valley. Dozens of bears are shot in the Anchorage area every year by hunters, police, Fish and Game, and citizens.

Most hunts are managed to maintain or even increase populations, not to "thin" them. I think you're proposing that both black and brown bears be culled in the Anchorage area. Chugach State Park was created, in part, to maintain wildlife populations, including bears, for human use and enjoyment. Any bear hunts in or near areas populated by humans would be dangerous, both by shots fired by jittery hunters and by wounded bears running from the hunters.

Comment: I never watch them.  Couple of reasons.  

Since they are aimed at a mass market, the legal systems are mostly modeled after either California or New York.  The law is very State-specific, particularly on the criminal side.  Grand Jurys are done differently in Oregon, California and New York, for example.  

There is also the total difference between small legal offices and larger offices.  Even in Oregon the We The People Firms in Portland have little to do with legal practice in much smaller offices and communities.

Then there is always the simplification of the law, the facts, and the investigations, whether in a criminal or a civil case that has to be built in to a television movie or series.  

Law is basically boring repetitive Work!  Research is mandatory.  Without  Detailed preparation, you will lose!  When you ask a question or hear one being asked in a courtroom of any witness, if you don't already know the answer, you are not prepared.  

That doesn't happen without work.

Comment: TOL:  There are extremists on both tail ends of the continuum. Violence is, too often, a tactic of such groups and individuals.  Fortunately, those on the left haven't engaged in the mass killings we've seen from individuals on that far far right.

Comment: My husband and I have been researching the safety of the push-button or fingerprint activated safes; some can be defeated by a determined child, so that is our paramount concern. We've discussed our plans in case anything like this happens again (checking before we go inside, escape routes, etc.) and our first response would be to try to leave the house rather than to engage someone. IF the worst happens though, I'd like to be prepared. We would retreat to a room that locks, where we'd locate the quicker-opening safe. I'll admit I am not a big fan of guns, but my husband has taken me out shooting a number of times, I've taken some safety courses, and I have surprised myself by being a pretty good shot. He's in charge of cleaning everything, because it is an involved process. I try not to go places where I feel like I would need to carry one, but if I had to (emergency, wilderness trip gone bad), I hope I'd be prepared. We don't take it lightly.

Comment: Sports cars are a tiny portion of car sales. Porsche only sells 7~8K units in Canada a year. However Porsche's markup is an average $17250 per car, compared to $654 per car for GM. Porsche may be a niche automaker, but it is a very profitable and sustainable company.

Likewise, vinyl sales are a tiny portion of music sales, but the profit margins are significant. A vinyl record costs $2 to manufacture with markups often exceeding $20 per album. Digital downloads earn $2-$3 per album. Vinyl records may be a niche format, but is a profitable and sustainable format.

Comment: Anchorage, Fairbanks and the Mat-Su will be those most hurt by budget cuts and by cost-shifting from the Legislature to local governments. 
These cost increases being transferred to Alaska seniors who are spending their pensions here, and to parents and their near-college/trade school aged kids.

This transfer of costs, PLUS the job declines that begin this summer from the lack of oil industry and State-funded construction/exploration jobs, will only accelerate the departure of Alaska's budget-strapped middle class to opportunities elsewhere.

This is turn will lead to decreased local property values as empty home values will have to be sharply discounted to sell (as it was in the late '80's and early '90's). 

And this will mean property tax assessments and local revenue to the support the Muni will have to be adjusted sharply downward.
And this will mean more job losses and even lower property values.
I think you will start believing in the budget crisis very shortly.

By that measure of  completeness, you wouldn't have written a story but rather just posted a link to the decision. You are certainly aware that it is a journalistic standard to put things in context. Comment: So now you’re flagging my posts, then responding to them? You are the one confused by facts. The Realtor term is a trademark, it’s not a copyright issue. Being a realtor is like calling the box of Winco-brand tissues a box of kleenex; it’s not accurate, capitalized or not. If a real estate agent calls himself a realtor when he’s not a Realtor, or if Winco advertises its store-brand kleenex on sale, they’re going to get a letter from a lawyer.

Anyway, despite your crazy assertions, your friend Rick is a member of the Commercial Association of Realtors and is therefore a Realtor.
